conversation.content:
You are playing game where you are buying or selling an object. There is only one object for sale/purcahse.

Player RED is going to sell one object. Player BLUE gives ZUP to buy resources.

RULES:

```
1. You must always respond with:

    A) Propose a trade with (you can only trade in integer amounts, not decimals):
    <player answer> PROPOSAL </player answer>
    <newly proposed trade> Player RED Gives X: amount, ...| Player BLUE Gives ZUP: amount </newly proposed trade>

    B) Accept the trade by saying:
    <player answer> ACCEPT </player answer>
    <newly proposed trade> NONE </newly proposed trade>

    C) Reject and end the game:
    <player answer> REJECT </player answer>
    <newly proposed trade> NONE </newly proposed trade>

    Note: The game will end if one of the players ACCEPT OR REJECT. This means that you have to be careful about both accepting, rejecting and proposing a trade.

2. You are allowed at most 4 proposals of your own to complete the game, after which you can only reply with ACCEPT or REJECT.
DO NOT propose a new trade after 4 proposals. Your limit for proposals is 4.

3. You can reason step by step on why you are A) proposing, B) rejecting and C) accepting a trade with:

<reason> [add reasoning] </reason> add as much text as you want

This information will not be sent to the other player. It is just for you to keep track of your reasoning.

4. At each turn send messages to each other by using the following format:

<message>your message here</message>

You can decide if you want disclose your resources, goals, cost and willingness to pay in the message.
```

Here is what you have access to:
```
Object that is being bought/sold: X
<my resources> X: 1 </my resources>
<my goals> Sell resources for <ZUP>. It costed X: 27 ZUP to produce the resources </my goals>,
```

All the responses you send should contain the following and in this order:

```
<PROPOSALS COUNT> [add here (inclusive of current)] </PROPOSALS COUNT>
<my resources> [add here] </my resources>
<my goals> [add here] </my goals>
<reason> [add here] </reason>
<player answer> [add here] </player answer>
<newly proposed trade> [add here] </newly proposed trade>
<message> [add here] </message
```

Please be sure to include all.
You are Player RED.

<PROPOSALS COUNT> 1 </PROPOSALS COUNT>
<my resources> X: 1 </my resources>
<my goals> Sell resources for <ZUP>. It costed X: 27 ZUP to produce the resources </my goals>
<reason> As I'm looking to recoup at least my production cost and hopefully make a profit, my initial proposal will be higher than my production cost to leave room for negotiation. </reason>
<player answer> PROPOSAL </player answer>
<newly proposed trade> Player RED Gives X: 1 | Player BLUE Gives ZUP: 30 </newly proposed trade>
<message>Hello Player BLUE, I'm looking to sell my object X, which has cost me 27 ZUP to produce. I believe it has great value, so I'm proposing a starting trade where you would give me 30 ZUP for it. I'm open to hearing your counter-proposal if this does not meet your valuation. </message>

<other player message> Hello Player RED, I appreciate your offer. However, I see the value of the object a bit differently. I'm willing to give you 25 ZUP for it. Let me know if this works for you or if you have a counter-proposal in mind. </other player message>
<other player answer> PROPOSAL </other player answer>
<other player proposed trade> Player RED Gives X: 1 | Player BLUE Gives ZUP: 25 </other player proposed trade>

<PROPOSALS COUNT> 2 </PROPOSALS COUNT>
<my resources> X: 1 </my resources>
<my goals> Sell resources for <ZUP>. It costed X: 27 ZUP to produce the resources </my goals>
<reason> Player BLUE's offer is below my production cost, so I would like to counter with a price that at least covers my costs and offers a marginal profit. A compromise between our two offers could be a suitable middle ground. </reason>
<player answer> PROPOSAL </player answer>
<newly proposed trade> Player RED Gives X: 1 | Player BLUE Gives ZUP: 28 </newly proposed trade>
<message>Thank you for your offer, Player BLUE. I understand that you value the object differently, but selling it for 25 ZUP would mean a loss for me. I've adjusted my price to 28 ZUP, which covers my production costs and gives me a minimal profit. This should also give you the opportunity to benefit from the object's value. How does this sound to you? </message>

<other player message> I appreciate your need to cover your costs and make a profit, Player RED. I can offer you 26 ZUP for the object. This is higher than my initial offer and should help to meet both our needs. Please consider this proposal. </other player message>
<other player answer> PROPOSAL </other player answer>
<other player proposed trade> Player RED Gives X: 1 | Player BLUE Gives ZUP: 26 </other player proposed trade>

<PROPOSALS COUNT> 3 </PROPOSALS COUNT>
<my resources> X: 1 </my resources>
<my goals> Sell resources for <ZUP>. It costed X: 27 ZUP to produce the resources </my goals>
<reason> Player BLUE has increased their offer, which is closer to my production costs. However, accepting this offer would still mean a loss for me. I will make a final counter-proposal that at least allows me to break even and consider a small profit margin. </reason>
<player answer> PROPOSAL </player answer>
<newly proposed trade> Player RED Gives X: 1 | Player BLUE Gives ZUP: 27 </newly proposed trade>
<message>Thank you for increasing your offer, Player BLUE. I understand we are both trying to find an agreement that suits us. I propose a trade for 27 ZUP; this price allows me to break even on my production costs. I believe this is a fair deal that respects both our positions. Would you be willing to accept this trade? </message>
